title: Is Leaky Gut Syndrome Real?

content: Leaky gut syndrome (LGS) is a popular term making the rounds on the internet. Leaky gut syndrome is often blamed for brain fog, fatigue, weight gain, and other health problems. Find out if LGS exists, or if it’s just another wellness culture scam.
The small and large intestines are a 25-foot-long tube coiled inside your abdomen. The gut barrier lines the tube and protects the health of the gut as well as the rest of the body.

It may sound odd, but the gut must “leak” to support your wellbeing. In medical terms, this so-called leaking is referred to as “permeability.” A healthy gut barrier is permeable, but it’s picky about what it allows to leave the gut. The gut barrier is a smart filter with tiny gaps that allows water, nutrients, and other beneficial compounds into the bloodstream.

Infection, inflammation, or other damage to the gut barrier, which is often seen in intestinal diseases such as celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), and certain infections, enlarges gaps in the gut barrier. Bigger gaps allow compounds, including harmful bacteria, toxins, and undigested food, to seep into the blood and cause problems. This is called increased intestinal permeability or IIP.

sections.heading: Testing for Increased Intestinal Permeability
content: Influencers who portray LGS as the reason for health problems outside of the intestinal tract are usually trying to sell tests to determine LGS and get you to buy their solution to “heal” your gut. However, there is no single gold-standard test for LGS or IIP that is done regularly in a doctor’s office.

If you have an intestinal disease such as celiac disease or IBD, or ongoing severe diarrhea, your doctor may test you for IIP using endoscopy or special lab tests, after which they will try to determine what’s bothering you.
How to Support Gut Barrier Function

Leaky gut syndrome is not a diagnosis. It’s a wellness culture term related to IIP that’s been popularized by the internet. Though IIP is linked to certain intestinal conditions, the evidence for LGS as the cause for other symptoms, including chronic fatigue syndrome, allergies, and fibromyalgia, is minimal at best and mostly unreliable.

content: If you have an intestinal disease, it’s best to use a diet and prescribed medications specific to that condition to help maintain or improve the gut barrier. For example, people with celiac disease must avoid gluten, while those with IBD should follow doctor-recommended advice to reduce inflammation.

For everyone else, eating a balanced diet with adequate fiber, limiting or avoiding alcohol, and staying away from unnecessary antibiotics (which kill beneficial as well as bad bacteria in the gut) are useful ways to support gut health.

You also may want to resist the urge to take probiotic supplements unless your doctor advises them. Probiotic supplements are strain-specific, which means certain types of probiotics treat specific gut conditions.
